Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Real-time Oxygen Monitoring Instrument for Aircraft Fuel Tanks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be a safe and robust real-time O2 monitoring instrument for aircraft fuel tanks. This instrument will benefit the commercial aircraft industry by dramatically decreasing the probability of fuel tank explosions on planes and potentially save lives. This technology could also be used to insure that military plane and helicopter fuel tanks are adequately purged after they are pierced by ballistics, protecting both the aircraft and military personnel onboard. In addition, the technology developed by this project might be used to monitor the ullage in oil tankers and reservoir to prevent explosions, greatly benefiting oil industry and preventing oil spills. Finally, because this technology makes measuring O2 in harsh chemical environments possible, it might be applied to monitor O2 in the pharmaceutical and specialty chemical manufacturing process, where reduced O2 is often critical to protect expensive catalyst from fouling.


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop a safe and robust real-time O2 monitoring instrument for aircraft fuel tanks. Such an instrument is needed to address mandates from federal transportation safety agencies, which require commercial aircraft to eliminate the possibility of fuel tank explosions. The proposed instrument advances the state-of-the-art by employing a multi-component optical sensor based on the fusion of optical oxygen, temperature, and pressure sensors. The combination of these three robust, stable and sensitive sensors allows us to accurately and precisely measure O2 concentration in the range of temperatures, pressures and concentrations found in aircraft fuel tanks without the risk of spark hazards. The goal of Phase I will be to develop a prototype O2 monitoring instrument for aircraft fuel tanks and demonstrate that our technology can make safe, precise, and accurate O2 measurements in jet fuel vapors over an extend period of time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aimed to develop a safe and robust real-time oxygen monitoring instrument for aircraft fuel tanks. The FAA and NTSB highlight the potential for explosion caused by a buildup of oxygen in aircraft fuel tanks. On board inert gas generation systems have been developed to address this issue. However, the necessary technology to measure oxygen concentration in fuel tanks for real-time feedback of the inert gas generation system does not currently exist. Modern commercial oxygen sensors pose explosion hazards due the nature of the measurement. Current systems also drift with changes in temperature and in some cases cannot withstand contact with jet fuel. This means the current approaches to measuring oxygen in fuel tanks are unable to meet the accuracy, longevity, cost, and weight requirements for use in an aircraft.

The outcome of this SBIR Phase I was an optically based prototype oxygen sensor capable of monitoring oxygen in a jet fuel tank. The use of optical rather than other sensing methods removed all risk of combustion hazard in an aircraft fuel tank. The prototype oxygen sensor was calibrated and found to be highly accurate at near flight conditions. Furthermore, it was able to monitor oxygen in a simulated jet fuel tank for 25 days, and passed an off-site Boeing aircraft component prequalification test. Due to the success of the Phase I project, this prototype oxygen sensor could be further developed into a commercially ready, safe and robust real-time oxygen fuel sensor for aircraft fuel tanks. The oxygen fuel sensor will benefit the commercial and military aircraft industry by decreasing the probability of fuel tank explosions. Moreover, with minor revisions the oxygen fuel sensor may be applicable across a wider array of enclosed fuel containers such as those used on railcars and tankers.
